musicalLanguage.description: A Latin jazz classic that blends bossa nova rhythm with jazz harmony. The tune sits primarily in C minor with a brief detour to Db major, creating a beautiful key-center shift. The bossa groove in the left hand should be steady and understated — think Rio, not New York.
musicalLanguage.structure: 16-bar form (this excerpt: first 8 bars in C minor)
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: Cm7 establishes the minor mood with bossa rhythm
Bar 3-4: Fm7 — the iv chord adds depth to the minor tonality
Bar 5-6: Dm7b5 to G7 — the classic minor ii-V, pulling toward resolution
Bar 7-8: Cm7 — home. The ii-V resolves beautifully.
teachingGoals: Bossa nova left-hand pattern — root on 1, chord on the 'and' of 2
Minor ii-V-i progression: Dm7b5 - G7 - Cm7
Smooth voice leading between closely related chords
styleTips: Bossa nova is gentle — no heavy accents, let the rhythm flow
Left hand should be legato and quiet, creating a cushion
Right hand melody is lyrical and singing — think of a vocalist

measures.leftHand: C3:q R:e Eb3 G3:e R:q Bb3:q
measures.teachingNote: Cm7 with bossa pattern. The melody leaps up to Eb5 then steps down.

measures.leftHand: C3:q R:e Eb3 G3:e R:q Bb3:q
measures.teachingNote: Still on Cm7. The melody is simple and vocal — singable.

measures.leftHand: F3:q R:e Ab3 C4:e R:q Eb4:q
measures.teachingNote: Fm7 — the iv chord. Left hand shifts the bossa pattern up to F.

measures.leftHand: F3:q R:e Ab3 C4:e R:q Eb4:q
measures.teachingNote: Second bar of Fm7. Melody gently ornaments around the chord tones.
Dm7b5 — the ii chord of the minor ii-V. The Ab in left hand is the b5.
G7 — the V chord. B natural is the major 3rd that creates the pull to Cm.

measures.leftHand: C3:q R:e Eb3 G3:e R:q Bb3:q
measures.teachingNote: Cm7 — resolution! The ii-V-i is complete. The melody celebrates the arrival.
Cm7 continues. The rest in the melody creates space before the next section.
